awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Stochastic Computing-based Host Intrusion Detection System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide an extra layer of security protection for Internet of Things (IoT) devices by using a novel hardware-based intrusion detection system. In today's defense-in-depth security strategy, all available security controls are placed in series aiming to protect a device from malicious cyber-physical attack.  Market research estimates that the IoT market will reach over $500B by 2021 and security is considered one of the biggest barriers in adopting IoT.  One main reason of this security concern is due to the limited resource of IoT devices that makes it difficult to apply all layers of security protections. The adoption of the proposed approach will provide additive security layer to the IoT devices that will boost the confidence in IoT device security in cameras, drones, sensors and others. Consequently, it may induce new industries which have previously been reluctant to apply IoT solutions to their businesses. Due to the small resource occupation of the proposed device security, even non-IoT industries may apply the proposed approach to their security applications.

This I-Corps project applies Stochastic Computing (SC) to provide hardware Host Intrusion Detection System (HIDS) security solution for resource limited IoT devices. Current approaches to IoT security cannot provide HIDS solution to these resource constraint IoT devices, thereby missing out from one of the important layers in defense-in-depth security strategy. The proposed approach exploited two salient properties of SC: 1) consumption of less silicon area and power, 2) both SC and HIDS are inherently probabilistic in nature. SC is generated probabilistically from conventional number system that can perform complex mathematical operation using simple hardware blocks. The proposed approach provides IoT devices with HIDS based on simple hardware together with Machine Learning Neural Network Algorithm. Coupled with other security layers such as cryptography, access control etc., this light weight hardware solution provides strong security to the resource limited IoT devices. Embedded inside the IoT device, this HIDS monitors the incoming packets for any malicious activity and offers the last important layer of security defense.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stochastic Computing-based Host Intrusion Detection System (HIDS) for IoT devices

NSF I-Corp Project Summary

The main tenet of today's security is the defense-in-depth. Devoid of some layers may make an IoT device insecure. The connection of such a device to the open internet is nothing but waiting for a disaster to happen. However, the Host Intrusion Detection System (HIDS), one of the layers for security, is difficult to implement in these resource constraint IoT devices because: 1) software based HIDS requires significant amount of resources; 2) hardware based HIDS is not in the market yet.

The goal of the NSF I-corp is to find commercial opportunities of the proposed Stochastic Computing-based Host Intrusion Detection System (HIDS). Specifically, the activities include: to find product market-fit, to find customers who are in immediate need of the product, and to identify Minimum Viable Product (MVP).  The NSF I-Corp Kick-off workshop and follow-up customer discovery activities result in meeting (in-person and phone calls) more than 120 potential customers and partners. A target market is determined to be industrial UAV (drone). Mutual collaboration achieved with four partner drone manufacturers and companies who also offered support letters for our successful NSF STTR Phase I award.

Intellectual Merits

In the proposed SC-based HIDS, two salient features of SC are exploited:  1) consumption of less silicon area and power thus a good match for resource constrained IoT devices; 2) probabilistically computed, hence, well suited for inherently probabilistic HIDS. With SC-based hardware, complex mathematical functions can be processed using simple digital logic gates in the stochastic domain. The proposed HIDS applies Machine Learning Neural Network Algorithm (NNA) in SC-domain for the first time. Popular attack data set NSL-KDD is used to train and test our HIDS. A proof-of-concept demo system was successful. The test results show a 80% reduction of silicon area using SC-based HIDS compared to the two's complement-based and the accuracy of intrusion detection reaches 98%. Our hardware-based HIDS will improve the processing speed by several times compared to software solutions, which will be the first HIDS for drones in the market 

Broader Impacts

IoT promises to transform the way we work, live, and play but not without critical challenges.  The hacking of IoT devices and privacy fears already grabbed public attention. If the issue of IoT security is not resolved in a timely manner, the envisioned connected world built on IoT, may be a story in the distant future.  According to several surveys, the security issue is the biggest obstacle to efforts to integrate IoT into companies? businesses. Our vision is to protect first industrial drone and later IoT devices through SC hardware-based HIDS  and to help the connected world be realized in all industries. Currently, no HIDS exists in the IoT device market.  The HIDS chip will be provided to IoT vendors by OEM basis, which will allow IoT vendors to offer secure products and to grow their sales rapidly.

Having confidence in IoT device security, even new industries like medical industry which have been reluctant to apply IoT to their business will join the band.  This provides us ample opportunity to commercialize our  HIDS for IoT devices in numerous industry sectors. Moreover, because of its improved speed (hardware based with small silicon footprint), our HIDS may attract other non-IoT device manufacturers.
